Subject: Music
Definition: In music, the way a note is sung or played, such as short and detached (staccato), smooth (legato) or accented, which contributes to the overall style and interpretation.

Subject: Music
Definition: Individuals or groups of people who experience the arts in a range of settings and contexts (formal, informal, virtual or interactive) through intellectual, emotional and social engagement. The artist is audience to their own artwork.

Subject: Music
Definition: Aural skills are listening skills used to identify and analyse specific elements of music, such as the duration of a note, the interval (distance) between 2 notes or the structure/quality of a chord. Aural skills complement purposeful or active listening and can be used when listening, composing and performing sounds.

Subject: Music
Definition: An abbreviated form of music notation that describes the basic harmonic and rhythmic information for a song.

Subject: Music
Definition: In music, a piece of music or music work.

Subject: Music
Definition: Approaches or devices used to manipulate and organise sound (e.g. motif, repetition, abstraction, sequence, transition, contrast, variation, canon, inversion, unison, ground bass, imitation).

Subject: Music
Definition: Traditionally, stylistically or culturally accepted ways of doing things. Each art form has hundreds of conventions built up over time. Conventions are dynamic and ever-changing.

Subject: Music
Definition: Legal rights in creative work (e.g. text, images, music, computer programs, sound recordings, film). The creator or copyright owner has the right to prevent others copying the work without permission.

Subject: Music
Definition: The physical environment that a particular Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples' group has a relationship with. Referring to this territory as 'Country', rather than land, indicates a reciprocal and deep relationship and one where Country both owns and is owned by the People. The concept of Country includes lands, waters and sky.

Subject: Music
Definition: A body of beliefs, attitudes, languages, skills, knowledge, laws, customs and tools by which communities structure and organise their lives and interactions.

Subject: Music
Definition: Digital hardware, software, platforms and resources used to develop and communicate learning, ideas and information. In music, this includes digital audio workstations (DAWs) and other digital tools for making and producing music, for recording and notating, and to assist in rehearsing and practising music skills.

Subject: Music
Definition: Written symbols that represent and communicate sound. Notation can be invented, recognisable to a traditional style or culture, or digitally created.

Subject: Music
Definition: In music, dynamics and expression refers to how the sound is performed, including sound qualities (e.g. the relative volume and intensity of sound).

Subject: Music
Definition: Duration (including tempo, rhythm and metre): the organisation of sound and silence and their lengths in music. Pitch: the relative highness or lowness of sound. Pitch occurs horizontally (as in a melody) and vertically (as in harmony). Tone colour/timbre: the characteristic quality of sound sources and their combinations. Texture: how sounds are combined, and how they interact and function as a piece of music (layers of sound). Structure/form: the organisation of a piece of music described by identifying what is the same and what is different and the ordering of ideas in the piece. Dynamics: the relative volume (loudness) and intensity of sound. Articulation: how specific notes or passages are played or sung, for example detached (staccato), smooth (legato), plucked (pizzicato) or accented.

Subject: Music
Definition: Describes aesthetic, sensory, cognitive and physical engagement through stillness, movement, exploration of space or working with materials, used to generate, develop or communicate ideas or meaning.

Subject: Music
Definition: The manipulation of the elements of music and compositional devices to create specific effects in a personal response to the music.

Subject: Music
Definition: The structure of a music work (e.g. 32-bar song form, 12-bar blues, binary/AB or theme and variations).

Subject: Music
Definition: In music, a term that implies an accepted class, type or category of music that adheres to a shared tradition, set of conventions or common characteristics or quality, such as opera, string quartet, jazz trio, marches, fanfares and dance music.

Subject: Music
Definition: In music, extending and varying music ideas in response to initial material or responses to music ideas generated by other performers.

Subject: Music
Definition: The rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples to own and control their cultural heritage. It refers to all aspects of cultural heritage, including the tangible (e.g. cultural objects) and intangible (e.g. knowledge).

Subject: Music
Definition: The distance between one pitch and another.

Subject: Music
Definition: A form of music notation specifying only the essential elements of a popular song, usually the melody, lyrics and chords.

Subject: Music
Definition: Auditory awareness, discrimination, memory, sequencing and imagination may be demonstrated by oral, written or physical responses to hearing music works or isolated elements of music.

Subject: Music
Definition: Relating to more than one art form.

Subject: Music
Definition: Playing, creating, composing or arranging music.

Subject: Music
Definition: A process by which music is created, captured, manipulated and preserved using digital tools.

Subject: Music
Definition: Written symbols that represent and communicate sound. Notation can be invented, recognisable to a traditional style or culture or digitally created.

Subject: Music
Definition: These are evident when well-prepared music is presented confidently to an audience with focus and clear intentions.

Subject: Music
Definition: A type of expression communicated for a particular effect with distinguishing features and appearance, performance styles are defined by the way conventions and other elements are used in performance.

Subject: Music
Definition: Ability to understand music works at a deeper level, and experiment with a variety of techniques and interpretations to make critical decisions about how a final performance will be executed.

Subject: Music
Definition: In music, the highness or lowness of a sound.

Subject: Music
Definition: Being mindful of whether you are singing or playing at exactly the same pitch as someone else, or whether you are higher or lower.

Subject: Music
Definition: 'Place' is significant for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples. For Torres Strait Islander Peoples, 'Place' is a space mapped out that Torres Strait Islander individuals or groups occupy and regard as their own and that has varying degrees of spirituality. It includes lands, waters and sky. For Aboriginal Peoples, 'Place' refers to the special places that exist within Country, the purposes of which vary significantly. They can include places of ceremony and initiation, birth and the provision of healing and health care; places of learning; and places for Sorry Business. These places vary greatly over the various landscapes and seascapes across the continent. There are some parts of Country that have landmarks that directly relate to the ancestor spirits and the creation of existence. These are especially important as culturally significant places and need to be cared for. There are also other places on Country that are important for ceremony, as mentioned above, which are also considered especially important for Aboriginal communities.

Subject: Music
Definition: The application of arts skills and knowledge to create, represent, communicate and respond in a specific arts discipline, form, tradition, style and/or genre. In any arts discipline, the practices of making and responding are interdependent and interactive. For example, the practices of interpreting, analysing, comparing, contrasting, reflecting, evaluating and appreciating can inform the art-making process. In music, practices include listening, improvising, composing, arranging, conducting, singing, playing, recording, notating, practising, rehearsing, presenting and performing.

Subject: Music
Definition: Regularly revise, develop and consolidate skills, techniques and repertoire as a class or as an individual.

Subject: Music
Definition: Rules, practices and customs of a group. Respectful ways of interacting with and experiencing the arts, including protocols for protecting Indigenous Cultural and Intellectual Property (ICIP) rights.

Subject: Music
Definition: Taking an existing music work and making alterations (small or large) to elements of music to change the feel or style of the existing work.

Subject: Music
Definition: In music, combinations of long and short sounds that convey a sense of movement; the subdivision of sound within a beat.

Subject: Music
Definition: A collection of notated representations of sound used to communicate musical information. Scores can use graphic, traditional, invented or stylistically specific symbols.

Subject: Music
Definition: The linking together of a series of ideas, much like words are linked together to form sentences and paragraphs. In music, a sequence is a melodic, rhythmic or harmonic pattern that is repeated. It can also describe the process or product of arranging blocks of music using 'sequencing' software.

Subject: Music
Definition: In Western music notation, the set of 5 horizontal lines and 4 spaces that are used to represent pitch.

Subject: Music
Definition: Anything that acts as inspiration for generating or developing ideas for artworks, including the world of the student, images, experiences, observations, provocations, sounds and texts.

Subject: Music
Definition: The distinctive characteristics of an arts form, artwork and/or arts practice that allow them to be grouped into related categories by culture, time, place, instruments used, etc. (e.g. romantic, hip hop, country or minimalism).

Subject: Music
Definition: Combination of proficiencies in control, accuracy, alignment, strength, balance and coordination in an art form that develop with practice. In music, this includes proficiencies developed with practise in order to sing or play instruments.

Subject: Music
Definition: In music, the capacity to control a voice or instrument in order to produce, control and vary a desired sound.

Subject: Music
Definition: The particular tone, colour or quality that distinguishes sound or combinations of sounds.

Subject: Music
Definition: In music, tone refers to the particular characteristics of a sound. A tone is also a description used to measure the distance of one pitch from another. A semitone is the distance on a keyboard from one note to the very next note (black or white) and a tone is the distance of 2 semitones.

Subject: Music
Definition: Ideas and beliefs specific to individuals and groups.

Subject: Music
Definition: A collection of perspectives, lenses or frames through which artworks (including music works) can be explored and interpreted.
